title: 115_hr2888
content: The Act may be cited as the "Ste. Genevieve National Historical Park Establishment Act". The Act establishes definitions for terms like Historic District, Historical Park, Map, Secretary, Special resource study, and State. Establishment of the Ste. Genevieve National Historical Park. The Ste. Genevieve National Historical Park is established to preserve French settlement, architecture, and farming on the frontier. Conditions for establishment include acquiring sufficient land and entering into written agreements with relevant entities. The boundaries of the Ste. Genevieve National Historical Park are depicted on the Map and available for public inspection. The Secretary has the authority to acquire land within the park through donation, purchase, or exchange. The Secretary will revise the Historical Park boundary to include acquired properties. The park will be administered according to specific laws and a management plan must be developed within 3 years. The Secretary must prepare a general management plan for the Historical Park within 3 years of funds availability. The plan will be submitted to Congress, and interpretative tours and educational programs may be provided at related sites within the Historic District. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with owners of significant properties in the Historical Park or Historic District to improve and restore them, providing access for visitors. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with property owners in the Historical Park or Historic District for conducting visitors and interpreting the property. The Federal share of costs should not exceed 50%, and the non-Federal share can be in the form of donated property, goods, or services. No changes can be made to the property without agreement. Any payment by the Secretary under this subsection for property conversion, use, or disposal must adhere to an agreement ensuring reimbursement to the United States for any misuse of funds or increased property value. The Secretary is not authorized to take financial responsibility for the operation, maintenance, or management of the Historic District.
